text:
Efficiently? Don't rush it and try and find shortcuts. Otherwise, you'll just have to do it all over again very soon. And 100 posts is a mammoth task.

Spend time working out what needs to be updated, what just doesn't work, and the priority of the articles (traffic, conversion, sales enablement etc).

Make a list if you don't already (could be Notion, AirTable or a simple spreadsheet) and work through them one by one.

For increased _speed,_ hire some freelancers who specialise in this area.

speed,

text: For a community post that came into my head as I was walking the dogs this morning: For you, what's the best thing about being a freelancer? Will give full credit and a backlink :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: For a community post that came into my head as I was walking the dogs this morning: For you, what's the best thing about being a freelancer? Will give full credit and a backlink

text: being able to choose who i work with, and having the independence to fire poor clients

elements.text: being able to choose who i work with, and having the independence to fire poor clients

text: I don't have to work a set number of hours every day. I can ramp up or ramp down as I please. Also, I can choose when to sleep. :smile:

elements.text: I don't have to work a set number of hours every day. I can ramp up or ramp down as I please. Also, I can choose when to sleep.

text: Love this post Ryan, thank you. Low effort/high impact is :ok_hand: right now.

elements.text: Love this post Ryan, thank you. Low effort/high impact is
right now.

text: It’s an opportunity to write for several different audiences, industries, and topics!

elements.text: It’s an opportunity to write for several different audiences, industries, and topics!

text: +1 to <@U012GHRAHDK>'s answer. The flexibility and non-existent commute was a big bonus for me, even before the pandemic hit. I'm someone who tends to work in big bursts, so if I need 4 days in a row to putter around I can usually find that time, and if I want to work from 1pm to 3am straight, I can do that too (and sleep in til 11 the next day with minimal concern)

elements.text: +1 to

's answer. The flexibility and non-existent commute was a big bonus for me, even before the pandemic hit. I'm someone who tends to work in big bursts, so if I need 4 days in a row to putter around I can usually find that time, and if I want to work from 1pm to 3am straight, I can do that too (and sleep in til 11 the next day with minimal concern)

text: The best thing about freelancing is the compounding value of the work that I do and the flexibility that comes after years of refinement. Really, it's being able to say "no" to projects that aren't a fit.

elements.text: The best thing about freelancing is the compounding value of the work that I do and the flexibility that comes after years of refinement. Really, it's being able to say "no" to projects that aren't a fit.

text: From an SEO perspective, which tool is the best for measuring website health + speed? Currently looking at: Google Lighthouse, Pingdom, GTMetrix, Google Analytics, and Google PageSpeed Insights.

elements.text: From an SEO perspective, which tool is the best for measuring website health + speed? Currently looking at: Google Lighthouse, Pingdom, GTMetrix, Google Analytics, and Google PageSpeed Insights.

text: haha, so many to choose from! Are you seeing wildly different results between them?

elements.text: haha, so many to choose from! Are you seeing wildly different results between them?

text: The main ones I check when I'm looking to improve things are GTMetrics and PageSpeed Insights (which shows lighthouse data IIRC).

elements.text: The main ones I check when I'm looking to improve things are GTMetrics and PageSpeed Insights (which shows lighthouse data IIRC).

text: Yes! For Pingdom + GTMetrix we're ranked in the 70-90th percentile depending on the page but for Lighthouse we're in the 10-40th percentile.

elements.text: Yes! For Pingdom + GTMetrix we're ranked in the 70-90th percentile depending on the page but for Lighthouse we're in the 10-40th percentile.

text: So trying to figure out which one is the best indicator or website performance from an SEO perspective!

elements.text: So trying to figure out which one is the best indicator or website performance from an SEO perspective!

text: I wouldn't worry about percentile. From an SEO perspective, I would want pages loading under 2 seconds and checking to see what the culprits are that make them take longer.

elements.text: I wouldn't worry about percentile. From an SEO perspective, I would want pages loading under 2 seconds and checking to see what the culprits are that make them take longer.

Yes, I use GTmetrix and Pingdom on every site I make. GTmetrix really digs in and shows you what you need to improve.

Just try to get the site load time down under 2 like Brendan mentioned.

text: +1 for GTMetrix. I've also used <http://Speedmonitor.io|Speedmonitor.io> to benchmark Google PSI scores over time which has been great to see change over time based on technical and on-site changes made by tech teams. You can benchmark your own pages and competitors and watch for trends/change over time.

to benchmark Google PSI scores over time which has been great to see change over time based on technical and on-site changes made by tech teams. You can benchmark your own pages and competitors and watch for trends/change over time.

Let me know if anyone else has anything they think is the best thing about being a freelancer and I'll add it to this growing list.

Side note: I did this an experiment to see if I could write a 1000 word blog post in half an hour. Result: I had 3 seconds to spare!

root.text:
Hi Friends! Over at Wildbit (where I’m the head of marketing), we have a “Wildbench” of freelancers and consultants that we work with. The Wildbench has great representation from women, but I’ve been trying to introduce some BIPOC folks into the picture.

Browsing through some of the channels and conversations here I discovered Writers of Color (thank you!) and <#CJE3XC44V|job-listings> (wonderful resource!). I haven’t spotted a place where folks can say “I’m available for hire!” or a directory of folks along with their specialities — unless I’m missing it?

By way of example, the Email Geeks community has a <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1klz8ob5iFFB4LmH4G5EVdtF1ywHbysLvvOTQi70u_tg/edit#gid=0|shared Google Sheet> they use for this (along with a channel), although I imagine an Airtable with filters may be better :slightly_smiling_face: As a hiring manager, I’d love to see such a resource created by this community if it doesn’t already exist.

text: Yeah, the last thing you want to do is rush things. A performance audit would be a good place to start, to see where the value is coming in from. You could consolidate posts that overlap with the strongest of the bunch.  You could also identify which ones are due for complete overhauls, versus some that just need optimization. I'd group them into buckets of action items (redirect, update, overhaul, remove, etc). I think if you've got a framework to outline what you have to do, it'll be easier to do right the first time.

elements.text: Yeah, the last thing you want to do is rush things. A performance audit would be a good place to start, to see where the value is coming in from. You could consolidate posts that overlap with the strongest of the bunch.  You could also identify which ones are due for complete overhauls, versus some that just need optimization. I'd group them into buckets of action items (redirect, update, overhaul, remove, etc). I think if you've got a framework to outline what you have to do, it'll be easier to do right the first time.

text: Yep, I would create an update-focused content calendar to start working off of instead of one for new content creation, and it might help cognitively for your writers to organize them into campaigns or themes so they can spend a month or so going deep on one topic at a time.  You might also want to start with the highest-converting ones more than the high trraffic ones so early results can act as a motivator during the mid-project slump

elements.text: Yep, I would create an update-focused content calendar to start working off of instead of one for new content creation, and it might help cognitively for your writers to organize them into campaigns or themes so they can spend a month or so going deep on one topic at a time. there could have been an update too: <https://www.seroundtable.com/google-search-algorithm-update-on-october-28-30355.html>.

To get a better feel for whether or not your target audience is searching less, check out your impressions in Google Search Console. And for instance compare them to last week.
